story:
Hello all, I know the year has been difficult for everyone, so I thought it would be good to start 2021 with a bit of positivity and spirit, as I intend to do a fundraiser through January. My sister was diagnosed with breast cancer back in September at the age of 25, and has been going through chemotherapy during the pandemic with my family effectively isolating since September. During her treatment she has been supported by Macmillan, who have provided crucial information for her, as well as providing a network to support her if the need ever arose . My sister has shown incredible resilience, and I cannot begin to describe my pride for her, for this reason I want to support those who can actively support my sister, as well as other cancer sufferers.
I realise over the pandemic that many organised events, such as marathons and other fundraising events have not been able to go ahead, which makes supporting groups such as Macmillan more crucial than ever.

story: Like pretty much everyone I've had a relative affected by cancer. My grandfather died of colorectal cancer in his late 70s when I was too small to grasp the absolute certainty of death. He was blessed to have been able to be in his own home with 2 of his children. Looking back now I think how the excellent palliative services we have now would have made it so much easier for him in his final weeks. McMillan cancer nurses are a lifeline for the patient and family and an invaluable source of support for health professionals for providing the best care for cancer patients. We often associate McMillan cancer support with palliative care but they do so much more such as providing information and supporting patients through their diagnosis and treatment, being their advocate and providing valuable financial advice. The NHS is under immense pressure because of the pandemic. Cancer care has also been hugely impacted and McMillan plays a valuable role in helping to take off some of this pressure. I hope by this small fundraising venture to show how accessible running is for everyone. You don’t have to “look” or “feel” like a runner to be one..I certainly don’t. You just have to love it and want to keep doing it. Honestly if I can do this pretty much anyone can. As a recent couch to 5k graduate I am still really slow and this will definitely be a challenge but its not necessarily about being fast and running more miles but just enjoying the process. As a busy working mum with 2 kids it has been an invaluable source of stress relief. It's funny how my love for running started with a fundraiser and I remember running for the sake of the fundraising rather than for the sake of the run and yes, how I once hated it. Charities such as McMillan have suffered a huge blow to their finances as so many of their regular fundraising events have been cancelled due to the pandemic. Like so many of us I am caught in the treadmill of work and looking after family and so little time to do anything else besides such as volunteering or fundraising. This is just a small attempt to come off that treadmill for a little while and hoping to help make a small difference for the better in the lives of others.

I'm riding in memory of a Colin Watson, a close friend and cycling companion. Colin died suddenly of acute heart failure whilst our riding in August 2021. He gave so much to those around him with his enthusiasm for the outdoors, and dedicated a great deal of his time to charities and causes in aid of a greener, more  just and sustainable world. 

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. As many of you may know we sadly lost Kay on the 13th of  December after her battle with lung cancer. Two years ago Kay also suffered a heart attack which left her in hospital for 9 weeks but after defying many odds she came home fighting and returned to work at the bay tree. 

Due to corona virus we are only able to have a limited  number of people to attend Kay’s funeral. Her wish was for any donations to go to The British heart foundation so for this reason I am setting up this page so anyone that can not attend the funeral has the option to make a donation as a tribute to Kay. 

Kay was an amazingly strong lady and loved by many. It is a heartbreaking loss for all of her family and everyone that knew her so any donation made from the people that knew and loved Kay would be greatly appreciated as it can go towards our own donation to the foundation. 

Thank you for reading

After the sudden loss of my beloved Dad to the silent killer of heart disease, I wanted to try and raise money to support the vital work of the British Heart Foundation. 

This half marathon is so far out my comfort zone, its crazy but I am hoping crazy will save lives of other people.

By Supporting me, we can help fight this disease together, and stop the heart break for other families that my family have had to endure. 

I know finances are very tough for everyone at the moment, but if you find it to donate even £1 that would be amazing, and I thank you from the bottom of my heart.

story:
In 2021 we would love to help one of our chosen charities a little more than usual. 

Every year we sponsor a guide dog, in 2020 we’ve sponsored, Marley a beautiful little black lab pictured in the images. Next year our plan is to sponsor another puppy, plus sell our DFC calendars and help raise £250 for Guide Dogs UK. 

If you would like a DFC calendar for 2021 please donate £10 or more, then message us your name & address and we will send you one out. DFC are choosing to donate all funds towards this amazing charity.

The calendar is a big fella, it’s A3 so you get a lot of woof for your money. Technically they are a smidge smaller, the envelopes are A3 though. 

Find out more and why - 

Almost two million people in the UK are living with sight loss that has a significant impact on their daily lives. Of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone and lead lonely, isolated lives. Guide Dogs works for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life, for a world where being blind or partially sighted is not what defines you. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

Thank you in advance, Merry Christmas & a happy new year. 

Robin, Adam, Beth & Team DFC x

story: Great Ormond Street Hospital supports seriously ill children from all over the UK. Every day 619 children and young people arrive at GOSH to receive care and life saving treatments to ensure they can continue to lead healthy lives. Since 2012, Premier Inn and Restaurants have been proud partners of Great Ormond Street Hospital Charity and we know our passionate teams have taken part in many brilliant fundraising events as well as volunteering at national events around the country and at the hospital. During these uncertain times our teams continue to achieve incredible things, challenging themselves to conquer their Everest and take care of their wellbeing. story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our just giving page! 

KM for Kyle

2020 has been an extremely difficult year for most, especially for our colleagues and families working tirelessly on the thin blue line.

As many of you have been made aware our friend and colleague PC 6506 Kyle Burns has been diagnosed with a very rare and terminal form of cancer. Kyle has been working on response Team 5 Cardiff City Centre after transferring from Gwent Police having also previously worked for the Met. 

Kyle is a prime example of a hard working police officer who has always looked to help and support his colleagues wherever possible.

Which is why we have organised ‘Kilometres for Kyle’. This is a simple challenge, as a collective we are asking police officers to come together and contribute towards the distance of 6506km which is Kyles Collar number. 

You can contribute by either Running, Cycling, swimming or walking. We ask that you join the ‘KM for Kyle’ Strava Club (Link Below) which will keep track of the total distance.

At the end of a very difficult year, all we ask is that you can contribute a distance and come together to support a friend and colleague who needs it now more than ever.

The Challenge will begin on the 26th December and we are aiming to achieve this distance by the 26th January.

Please find below the link for the Strava Club. Please join the club to contribute to the distance. 

https://www.strava.com/clubs/kmforkyle?utm_source=com.whatsapp&utm_medium=referral

Any donations will be extremely appreciated! 

Diolch Yn Fawr 

Thank you very much

pageSummaryWhy: I would like to raise money to help save wildlife
story:
IF YOU GO DOWN TO THE WOODS TODAY...

You might notice there’s less wildlife than there used to be. The latest in WWF’s flagship research series, the Living Planet Report, shows that our planet’s wildlife populations have now plummeted by 68% since 1970 – and there are no signs that this downward trend is slowing.

Half of all UK species are in decline – we’re losing our precious red squirrels, hedgehogs and birds at an alarming rate. When nature suffers, we all suffer. But we have a prescription, and if we act now we can protect our health and the health of our planet. 

By taking part in The Big Winter Wander, you and your friends and family can reconnect with our country’s beautiful wildlife and help protect it. The funds you raise will help us campaign to protect wildlife here, and around the world.

I am doing the big winter wander to raise money for WWF to aid the programmes they participate in to help save animals and prevent extinction. I want to raise awareness of the critically endangered species they help and want to educate others on human impact on nature and the environment. 

I want to also take this opportunity to go out and photograph native British species as well as species that have been brought to Britain. I want to document them and share them with others to help them better understand the world we live in.

I will hopefully be doing this walk with fellow nature lovers in a bid to raise money that will go towards the education of local communities living in close contact with the worlds most endangered animals as well as specialist equipment to monitor and track animal populations. 

Any amount is greatly appreciated. The target I’ve set is ambitious however even if I make half of it I’ll be happy that I’ve done my bit. Thank you for reading this and donating. Know you are playing your part in the global fight to save our planet.

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk
